fields.name: Title
fields.description: Full title of the study as stated in the paper
fields.value: Communication-based interventions to increase COVID-19 vaccine willingness and uptake: a systematic review with meta-analysis
fields.evidence_quote: Communication-based interventions to increase COVID-19 vaccine willingness and uptake: a systematic review with meta-analysis

fields.name: Author(s)
fields.description: List of all authors involved in the paper, in order of appearance
fields.value: Claire Iannizzi, Marike Andreas, Emma Bohndorf, Caroline Hirsch, Ana-Mihaela Zorger, Janine Brinkmann-Paulukat, Brigitte Bormann, Jessica Kaufman, Tina Lischetzki, Ina Monsef, Julia Neufeind, Nora Schmid-Küpke, Sebastian Thole, Karina Worbes, Nicole Skoetz
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Patient Co-authors
fields.description: Were any co-authors identified as patients or caregivers?
fields.evidence_quote: Patients and members of the public were not directly involved in this study.

fields.name: Journal
fields.description: Name of the journal where the study was published
fields.evidence_quote: BMJ Open

fields.name: Publication Stage
fields.description: Indicate if the paper is peer-reviewed, a preprint, or another stage
fields.evidence_quote: Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.

fields.name: Publication Date
fields.description: Official date the paper was published

fields.name: Field of Study
fields.description: Disciplinary or clinical field, such as primary care, oncology, or public health
fields.evidence_quote: Infection control

fields.name: Country
fields.description: Country or countries where the study was conducted or primarily situated
fields.value: USA, UK, China, Canada, Italy, Japan, Jordan, Australia, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Malaysia, Pakistan
fields.evidence_quote: Of the 49 identified studies, 22 studies were conducted in the USA,4 in the UK,4 studies were carried out in multiple country settings spanning countries globally, 3 in China,2 in Canada,2 in Italy,2 in Japan,2 in Jordan,1 in Australia,1 in Denmark,1 in France,1 in Germany,1 in Ireland,1 in Malaysia and 1 in Pakistan.

fields.name: Type of Article
fields.description: Classify the article: original research, protocol, review, commentary, etc.
fields.evidence_quote: Systematic review and meta-analysis

fields.name: Aim of Study
fields.description: State the main purpose or objective of the study as described by the authors
fields.value: To investigate the efficacy of communication strategies for increasing COVID-19 vaccine uptake and willingness compared with no intervention (with or without placebo interventions), or other intervention categories to increase COVID-19 vaccine uptake, or comparing different communication strategies with each other.
fields.evidence_quote: In this systematic review, we aimed to investigate the efficacy of communication strategies for increasing COVID-19 vaccine uptake and willingness compared with no intervention (with or without placebo interventions), or other intervention categories to increase COVID-19 vaccine uptake, or comparing different communication strategies with each other.

fields.name: Key Findings
fields.description: Summarize the main results or conclusions of the study
fields.value: Education and information-based interventions or social norm-framing strategies are most effective compared with no intervention, given that, in particular, they may increase COVID-19 vaccine uptake.
fields.evidence_quote: Overall, we found that education and information-based interventions or SNF strategies are most effective compared with no intervention, given that, in particular, they may increase COVID-19 vaccine uptake.

fields.name: Patient/Public Engagement (Y/N)
fields.description: Does the study report any involvement of patients or the public? This includes participation, feedback, consultation, or co-design.
fields.evidence_quote: Patients and/or the public were involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

fields.name: Type of Engagement (Montreal Model continuum)
fields.description: Categorize engagement based on the Montreal Model: Information, Consultation, Collaboration, or Partnership.
fields.evidence_quote: Together with relevant stakeholders from policy and research, we prioritised types of interventions and target populations and developed the PICO (Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome) for this systematic review.

fields.name: Evaluation of Impact (Y/N)
fields.description: Did the study evaluate or measure the effect of patient/public engagement?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Type of Evaluation
fields.description: What type of method or framework was used to evaluate the impact of engagement (e.g., metrics, qualitative feedback, evaluation framework)?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Impact of Engagement
fields.description: Describe any outcomes or changes attributed to patient/public engagement (e.g., design changes, improved recruitment, insights).
fields.value: Developed a relevant research question and prioritised types of interventions and target populations.
fields.evidence_quote: Together with relevant stakeholders from policy and research, we prioritised types of interventions and target populations and developed the PICO (Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome) for this systematic review.

fields.name: Participatory Process
fields.description: Did the study include a participatory design process such as workshops, co-design, or stakeholder sessions?
fields.evidence_quote: within this project, we invited different stakeholders to develop a relevant research question, based on the findings of our prior conducted scoping review, which maps the available evidence on interventions to increase COVID-19 vaccine intention of different populations.

fields.name: Continuous Evaluation Cycles
fields.description: Was engagement conducted iteratively or cyclically, with feedback loops or repeated interaction?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Implementation
fields.description: Did patient/public engagement influence the implementation strategy or process of the research?
fields.evidence_quote: Finally, we discussed the findings of this systematic review and the implementation of identified intervention strategies with experts from the Robert Koch Institute and the Center for Health in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany.

fields.name: Organization of Health Care
fields.description: Did engagement lead to reported changes in health care delivery, systems design, or institutional practice?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Persuasive Design Techniques
fields.description: Were behavior-change strategies or persuasive technologies mentioned (e.g., nudges, gamification, reminders)?
fields.evidence_quote: social norm framing (SNF) aiming at appealing to identity and moral values (2), gain framing (GF) focusing on advantages of adopting a recommended behaviour (3) and loss framing (LF) focusing on disadvantages of not performing the advocated behaviour (4)

fields.name: Assess Impact
fields.description: Did the study measure outcomes or success metrics related specifically to engagement efforts?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Information
fields.description: Was information provided to patients/public about the study, without involving them in decision-making?
fields.evidence_quote: education and information aiming to empower and inform people on topics related to COVID-19 vaccine

fields.name: Consultation
fields.description: Was patient or public input sought (e.g., through interviews, surveys, focus groups), without involving them in decision-making?
fields.evidence_quote: Together with relevant stakeholders from policy and research, we prioritised types of interventions and target populations and developed the PICO (Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome) for this systematic review.

fields.name: Collaboration
fields.description: Was there shared decision-making or co-design between researchers and participants in any phase of the study?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Partnership
fields.description: Were patients/public involved across all stages with formal roles (e.g., co-authors, advisory board, project governance)?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A
